Wii (pronounced /ˈwiː/) is a home video game console released by Nintendo on November 19, 2006. As a seventh-generation console, the Wii primarily competes with Microsoft's Xbox 360 and Sony's PlayStation 3.
Wii is a video game console made by Nintendo.

The Wii U is a home video game console developed by Nintendo as the successor to the Wii.
The Wii Remote, also known colloquially as the Wiimote, is the primary game controller for Nintendo’s Wii console.
Video game consoles are electronic devices that output a video signal or visual image to display a video game that one or more people can play.
A video game console is an electronic, digital or computer device that outputs a video signal or visual image to display a video game that one or more people can play.
A video game is an electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a video device such as a TV screen or computer monitor.
A video game is an electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a video device.

A video game is an electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a two- or three-dimensional video display device such as a TV screen, virtual reality headset or computer monitor.

Video games are electronic games that involve interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a two- or three-dimensional video display device such as a TV screen, virtual reality headset or computer monitor.
A television is an electronic device that displays moving images in monochrome (black-and-white), or in color, and in two or three dimensions and sound.
An object is a thing that can be seen or touched.
